Introduction

The stages of behavior change, as conceptualized by the transtheoretical model (TTM), which describes the process individuals undergo when modifying behavior and gauges their readiness for change.  This model can be applied to multiple habits and health-related decisions, including smoking cessation, exercise frequency, and medication adherence.  Identifying a patient's readiness for change allows for strategic, patient-centered interventions to decrease ambivalence and promote self-efficacy.

Transtheoretical model



The transtheoretical model (TTM) comprises the following stages (

figure 1
):



  • Precontemplation:  Views behavior as not needing change.
  • Contemplation:  Considers the risks and benefits of change (ambivalence).
  • Preparation:  Makes plans for the behavior change.
  • Action:  Enacts plans and behavior change.
  • Maintenance:  Sustains behavior changes.


Another component of the TTM includes relapse, which occurs if a patient reverts back to the problematic behavior after making a change (ie, during the action, maintenance phases).



The stages do not always occur in a linear manner (ie, can occur out of order or may not occur at all).  Experiencing ambivalence (ie, having conflicting feelings about change) and regressions is considered to be a normal part of the process.

Precontemplation



During the precontemplation stage, the patient does not view the behavior as problematic and may deny that it has any negative consequences.  Making a change is seen as "not worth it" or may be considered too hard/uncomfortable.

Clinical approach



Patients may avoid discussion of the behavior or become defensive when the topic is broached.  Motivation for change must come directly from the patient (ie, not imposed by the physician).  Use open-ended questions to explore the patient's current understanding of the behavior:



  • Express curiosity about the patient's experience with the behavior.
    • Example:  "How does drinking alcohol affect your ability to spend time with your family?"
  • Highlight discrepancy between the patient's goals/values and behavior (ie, identify the patient's goals/values and elicit how the behavior is inconsistent with them).
    • Example:  "Help me understand how skipping your medication fits in with your goal of not wanting to be in the hospital again."
  • Support self-efficacy and emphasize the patient's ability to change.
    • Example:  "You mentioned that you avoided going to the dentist for years and now you go regularly; how did you make that change?"
  • Avoid confrontation and advice, which may cause the patient to become defensive and more resistant to change.
    • Example:  "You need to cut down the amount of fast food you eat because your cholesterol levels are already very high."

Contemplation



The patient considers the pros and cons of the behavior but remains unsure whether making a change will be beneficial.

Clinical approach



Patients are ambivalent about change during the contemplation stage.  Meeting patients where they are (ie, not jumping ahead) while continuing to build on personal reasons for change may help resolve ambivalence.



  • Encourage discussion of pros and cons of behavior change.
    • Example:  "What do you like and dislike about eating healthier foods?"
  • Acknowledge the patient's feelings and explore barriers to change.
    • Example:  "What would keep you from quitting smoking at this time?"
  • Continue to highlight discrepancy between the patient's goals/values and behavior.
  • Discuss the benefits of change and provide evidence-based information.
    • Example:  "Would it be okay with you if I shared some information about how smoking cessation may improve your blood pressure?"

Preparation



The patient is committed to the behavior change (eg, "I'm ready to do something about my alcohol use") and has started to create a specific plan for action.

Clinical approach



Patients are committed to making a change but may be fearful of failing and not following through with their plan.  Continue to provide support and increase the patient's self-confidence during the preparation stage.



  • Collaborate on creating a clear, achievable action plan.
    • Example:  "What are some changes you have considered to lower your glucose levels?"
  • Encourage small initial steps and realistic short-term goals.
    • Example:  "Your first cognitive behavioral therapy appointment is next week.  What expectations do you have for that session?"
  • Address potential obstacles and discuss strategies to overcome them.
    • Example:  "What difficulties might you run into with this exercise schedule?  How would you overcome feeling unmotivated to exercise after a long day at work?"

Action



During the action stage, the patient believes in the ability to make a change and has started engaging in new, healthier behaviors.  The patient is actively seeking support from others (eg, 12-step program, counselor, friends/family).

Clinical approach



Providing ongoing support and encouragement is crucial during this stage of change.  There is a high risk for relapse, which may be due to unrealistic expectations of the time and effort required for change.



  • Reinforce positive behaviors and celebrate successes, no matter how small.
    • Example:  "You exercised once last weekâ€“great work!  How were you able to do that?"
  • Help the patient identify challenges and triggers for relapse and develop coping strategies.
    • Example:  "You've been taking your medication daily for 2 weeks.  What has been most helpful for you?  What difficulties have you noticed?"

Maintenance



During the maintenance stage, the patient's behavior change has been consistently maintained for >6 months.  The change has now become fully integrated into daily life, and the patient has increased confidence in the ability to continue the new behavior.

Clinical approach



Reinforcing the patient's ability to make a change and manage challenges helps bolster self-efficacy.  Although the risk for relapse diminishes over time, it remains present during the maintenance stage.  Identifying risk factors and prevention strategies for setbacks/regressions continues to be important.

Relapse



Relapse occurs if a patient reverts back to the problematic behavior after making a change (ie, during the action, maintenance, or termination phases).  It is not considered a stage of change.

Clinical approach



Patients often view relapses as failures, which can result in feelings of guilt, shame, frustration, and sadness.  Exploring the patient's emotions and providing validation are important first steps.



  • Normalize that relapse is a common part of the behavior change process.
    • Example:  "Maintaining new habits is hard for most people, you are not alone."
  • Help the patient identify what contributed to the setback.
    • Example:  "What do you think made it hard to take your medication?"
  • Reframe the setback as an opportunity to learn.
    • Example:  "What do you think worked? What didn't work?"
  • Identify the current stage of change and provide appropriate support.
    • Example:  "Are you interested in trying to stop smoking again?"

Motivational interviewing



Motivational interviewing is a patient-centered approach to help change maladaptive behaviors; it matches strategies to the patient's stage of readiness to make a change (

).  The goal is to develop the patient's own intrinsic motivation to change, rather than using pressure to motivate change.



Motivational interviewing is discussed in detail in a separate article.

Summary



The transtheoretical model describes the stages that typically occur when modifying a problematic behavior: precontemplation, contemplation, preparation, action, and maintenance.  Identifying the patient's current stage and level of readiness for change allows for tailored, collaborative interventions to increase internal motivation and promote long-term change.
